newsitem.title: UK: Coffee producers and consumers meet, ACPC follows.
newsitem.headline: Coffee producers and consumers meet, ACPC follows.

text.p: The International Coffee Organization (ICO) on Monday began a week-long meeting of producers and consumers with technical and practical issues firmly on the agenda.
The ICO, which groups 58 world consumers and producers, kicked off its meeting with an introductory Council session and key issues this week will centre on coffee promotion and ICO-backed projects.
"There will be some interesting technical presentations. And there will be discussions of various projects," said ICO spokesman Pablo Dubois said.
The Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC), representing some 80 percent of world output, will hold a meeting of its technical group on Friday and a full Council meeting on Saturday.

ACPC Secretary General Roberio Oliviera said the technical group on Friday will analyse figures for the group's 1995/96 export programme and figures for the first two months of the group's 1996/97 programme.
The ACPC last met in May when it agreed a new plan to limit green coffee exports from its 14 members to 53.5 million 60-kg bags in the year to June 1997 against 48.9 million in 1995/96.
In May Robusta coffee futures were trading at $1,970 a tonne, but have since slipped to their lowest level in over two years at $1,475 a tonne.

When asked if the ACPC was concerned about recent price falls, Oliviera said, "We are always concerned about the price evolution, especially when prices fall. We will analyse the market situation -- it is on the agenda," he added.
But traders said they are not expecting fireworks.
"The Association will contemplate the effectiveness of last year's and this year's export plans, so nothing substantial is expected to emerge from this gathering," broker GNI said.
On Tuesday, the ICO is expected to present its own analysis of the market situation.
Consumer delegates said they would welcome a presentation on the world market situation by ICO executive director, Celsius Lodder.
During the ICO's May meeting, Lodder did not draft an official document analysing the market nor issue market-sensitive forecasts which angered some delegates.
"It is crucial for an international commodity organisation to discuss the market situation," said one delegate.
Dubois said other presentations this week will include a report on wilt disease in Zaire, and a presentationn by a LIFFE official on the robusta coffee contract.
